title: Professor Atlas's Map Mystery
description: Follow Professor Atlas as he travels around Europe studying different countries and their borders using maps and special measuring tools.

briefing.headline: The Missing Map Equipment Case
briefing.narrativeHtml:
Learning Targets for Today:

  • I can use maps to identify European countries and their borders
  • I can explain how rivers and mountains make natural borders between countries
  • I can locate famous European cities and landmarks on a map
  • I can understand how people use tools to measure distances and make maps
  • I can identify different types of buildings and architecture in European cities

Your Mission: Help Sourdough Pete track down Professor Atlas! He's been taking special map-making equipment because he's obsessed with making the most accurate maps possible. He thinks he's improving geography, but taking things that don't belong to you is wrong! Follow the clues using your maps, globes, and research skills to find his European hideout.

What You'll Need: World map, map of Europe, globe, atlas, and internet for research about European countries and cities

Map Detective Challenge: Professor Atlas loves studying borders between countries and old European cities. Can you follow his trail through 5 European geography clues?

villains.name: Professor Atlas (Prof. Viktor Kowalski)
villains.title: Map-Making Teacher and European Geography Expert
villains.description: A geography teacher who loves making maps and studying how countries connect to each other. He gets so excited about perfect maps that he makes bad choices like taking equipment that doesn't belong to him.

rounds.clueHtml:
Map Detective Clue #1:

Professor Atlas was spotted in his map-making workshop! Here's what we know:

  • He has both old-fashioned compasses and modern GPS devices (like the maps on your phone!)
  • His workshop is full of rolled-up maps of European countries
  • He's near old castles and medieval towns with stone walls
  • He's comparing his hand-drawn maps with computer maps to make sure they match perfectly

Your job: Find a part of Europe that has lots of old castles and medieval towns where people study geography!
researchPrompts: Look on your Europe map for areas with lots of medieval castles
Research what tools people use to make maps
Find European countries with old stone castles and towns
Look up how GPS works (like maps on phones and tablets)
expectedProcess: Student identifies European regions with medieval architecture
Student learns about map-making tools and technology
Student connects castles to European countryside
Student understands how old and new map-making tools work together

reveal.trait: Uses both old and new map-making tools
reveal.note: Expert at combining hand-drawn maps with computer technology

rounds.explainHtml:
Great map detective work! You found the European countryside!

Professor Atlas works in areas of Europe that have lots of medieval castles and old stone towns. These places are perfect for studying geography because they show how people have lived in different places for hundreds of years. He uses both old tools (like compasses) and new tools (like GPS) to make the most accurate maps possible.

What You Learned:

  • Europe has many countries with old castles and medieval towns
  • Map-makers use different tools to measure distances and locations
  • GPS technology helps make maps more accurate
  • Old and new tools can work together to solve problems

rounds.clueHtml:
Map Detective Clue #2:

Professor Atlas is now studying rivers and how they form natural borders! Here's what we spotted:

  • He's standing at the edge of a deep river valley with his measuring equipment
  • The river has carved a deep path through the rocks over thousands of years
  • This winding river actually forms the border between two different countries!
  • He's using special tools to measure how wide and deep the river valley is

Your job: Research how rivers can form natural borders between countries in Europe!
researchPrompts: Look on your Europe map for rivers that form borders between countries
Research how rivers carve valleys through rock over time
Find European rivers that separate different countries
Look up the Rhine River or Danube River as examples
expectedProcess: Student identifies rivers as natural boundaries
Student learns how water erosion creates river valleys
Student finds examples of river borders in Europe
Student understands how natural features become country borders

reveal.trait: Studies natural borders and water features
reveal.note: Expert at measuring rivers and valleys that separate countries

rounds.explainHtml:
Excellent border detective work! You found a European river border!

Many countries in Europe use rivers as natural borders because rivers are easy to see and mark on maps. Over thousands of years, rivers cut deep valleys through rocks and create clear boundaries. The Rhine River, for example, forms part of the border between Germany and France. Rivers make good borders because they don't move much and everyone can agree on where they are.

What You Learned:

  • Rivers can form natural borders between countries
  • Water slowly carves valleys through rock over long periods of time
  • Natural features like rivers help define where one country ends and another begins
  • People use measuring tools to study the size and depth of rivers

rounds.clueHtml:
Map Detective Clue #3:

Professor Atlas is now in a beautiful old European city! Here's what we discovered:

  • He's standing in front of a tall cathedral with pointy towers and colorful stained glass windows
  • The city has old stone bridges crossing a river, and narrow streets with very old buildings
  • He's teaching other map-makers about how these old cities show where countries used to have their borders
  • The buildings are hundreds of years old and show different styles of European architecture

Your job: Find a famous old European city with cathedrals, stone bridges, and medieval buildings!
researchPrompts: Look up famous European cities with old cathedrals and stone bridges
Research Gothic cathedrals with tall spires and stained glass
Find European cities with medieval architecture and old buildings
Look up cities like Prague, Vienna, or Paris with historic centers
expectedProcess: Student researches European historic cities
Student learns about cathedral architecture and medieval buildings
Student identifies cities with stone bridges and old town centers
Student understands how old cities preserve historical boundaries

reveal.trait: Studies old cities and teaches other map-makers
reveal.note: Expert at finding historical clues in European architecture

rounds.explainHtml:
Amazing city detective work! You found a historic European city!

Many European cities have centers that are hundreds of years old, with tall cathedrals, stone bridges, and narrow streets. These old cities are like outdoor museums that show us how people lived long ago. The buildings and streets often follow the same patterns they had when countries had different borders. Cities like Prague, Vienna, and Paris have preserved their old centers so we can learn about European history.

What You Learned:

  • European cities often have historic centers with very old buildings
  • Cathedrals with tall spires are important landmarks in European cities
  • Stone bridges and medieval architecture tell us about the past
  • Old cities can show us how country borders used to be different

rounds.clueHtml:
Map Detective Clue #4:

Professor Atlas is now teaching geography at a university! Here's what we found:

  • He's in a big classroom with maps of Europe covering all the walls
  • He's wearing a green jacket and using a pointer to show students different countries
  • The students are learning about European borders and how they've changed over time
  • He has both physical maps (showing mountains and rivers) and political maps (showing country borders)

Your job: Research how geography teachers help students learn about countries, borders, and maps!
researchPrompts: Look up what geography teachers do in universities and schools
Research the difference between physical maps and political maps
Find information about how country borders in Europe have changed
Look up famous European universities that teach geography
expectedProcess: Student learns about geography education and teaching
Student understands different types of maps and their purposes
Student discovers how European borders have changed over time
Student connects classroom learning to real-world geography

reveal.note: Uses his teaching position to access map-making resources

rounds.explainHtml:
Outstanding education detective work! You found a university geography department!

Geography teachers help students learn about countries, borders, rivers, mountains, and how people live in different places. Universities have special geography departments where professors teach about maps, different countries, and how borders between countries have changed throughout history. These teachers use many different types of maps to help students understand our world better.

What You Learned:

  • Geography teachers help students learn about countries and borders
  • Universities have special departments for studying geography
  • There are different types of maps for different purposes
  • European country borders have changed many times throughout history

rounds.clueHtml:
FINAL Map Detective Clue:

We found Professor Atlas's secret plan! He's in his home country in Eastern Europe. Here's his final hideout:

  • He's in a beautiful old city with a cathedral, clock tower, and old defensive walls
  • This city is in Poland, a country in Eastern Europe between Germany and Russia
  • He's using his measuring equipment to document this historic city's old boundaries
  • He's been Professor Viktor Kowalski all along - a Polish geography expert!

Final Mission: You've followed Professor Atlas through his whole European adventure! Find his home country in Eastern Europe!
researchPrompts: Look on your Europe map for Poland and other Eastern European countries
Research famous Polish cities with old cathedrals and clock towers
Find Eastern European countries that are between Germany and Russia
Look up Polish names like Viktor Kowalski
expectedProcess: Student locates Poland on the map of Europe
Student learns about Eastern European countries and their locations
Student identifies Polish cities with historic architecture
Student understands Professor Atlas's true identity and home country

reveal.note: His real mission: Document the historic boundaries of his homeland!

rounds.explainHtml:
CASE SOLVED! You caught Professor Viktor Kowalski in Poland!

Professor Atlas's real name is Viktor Kowalski, and he's from Poland, a country in Eastern Europe. He loves studying the old boundaries and borders of Polish cities because he wants to preserve the history of his homeland. Poland has many beautiful historic cities with old cathedrals, clock towers, and medieval walls. Professor Kowalski cares so much about accurate maps that he made bad choices by taking equipment that didn't belong to him.

What You Accomplished:

  • You learned to use maps to find European countries and their borders
  • You discovered how rivers and mountains form natural boundaries
  • You researched historic European cities and their architecture
  • You understand how geography teachers help students learn about our world

Sourdough Pete says: 'Fantastic European detective work! You learned that loving geography and wanting perfect maps is wonderful, but there are right ways and wrong ways to pursue knowledge. Professor Kowalski should have asked permission instead of taking equipment that wasn't his!'

resolution.summaryHtml:
What Students Learned About European Geography:

  • Map-Making Tools: Compasses, GPS devices, measuring equipment for creating accurate maps
  • Natural Borders: How rivers and mountains form boundaries between European countries
  • Historic Cities: European cathedrals, stone bridges, medieval architecture, and old town centers
  • Geography Education: How teachers help students learn about countries, borders, and maps
  • Eastern Europe: Countries like Poland, their location, history, and cultural heritage
  • Country Borders: How European boundaries have changed over time and why they matter
  • European Culture: Different architectural styles, languages, and historic preservation

Why This Case Works for 11-Year-Olds:

Age-Appropriate Content: Map-making, borders, historic cities, and geography education

Map Skills: European countries, borders, rivers, historic cities, and cultural landmarks

Educational Progression: Map tools → river borders → historic cities → geography education → Eastern European heritage

Real Learning: European geography, border concepts, cultural appreciation, and map literacy!
learningExtensions: Learn more about European countries and their capitals
Research how rivers like the Rhine and Danube form country borders
Study different types of maps and what they show
Explore medieval architecture and historic European cities
Learn about Eastern European countries and their cultures
Practice using maps and globes to find countries and borders
Research careers in geography, map-making, and teaching
Learn about how European borders have changed throughout history
crossCurricular: Geography: European countries, borders, rivers, mountains, historic cities
History: Medieval architecture, European cultural heritage, border changes
Social Studies: Different European cultures, languages, and traditions
Math: Measuring distances, using coordinates, map scales and directions
Art: Drawing maps, European architecture, cathedral and castle designs
Technology: GPS systems, digital maps, modern vs traditional map-making
Language Arts: European country names, geographical vocabulary, research skills
